message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest serotonin syndrome, which is a potentially life-threatening adverse drug reaction that can occur with the use of serotonergic drugs such as SNRIs and SSRIs. Symptoms include hyperthermia, tachycardia, hypertension, tremors, altered mental status, and impaired coordination. Increased CNS serotonergic activity is the most likely cause of the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of serotonin syndrome, which can occur when two serotonergic drugs are taken together or when the dose of a single serotonergic drug is increased. In this case, the patient was switched to venlafaxine after citalopram did not work. Venlafaxine is also a serotonergic drug. Increased CNS serotonergic activity is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest serotonin syndrome, which is associated with the use of serotonergic medications such as venlafaxine and citalopram. Serotonin syndrome can cause hyperthermia, sweating, tachycardia, hypertension, tremors, and impaired gait. Increased CNS serotonergic activity is responsible for this syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest serotonin syndrome, which can be caused by increased CNS serotonergic activity. The recent switch from citalopram to venlafaxine could have caused the serotonin syndrome. Abnormal ryanodine receptor, dopamine receptor blockade, and anticholinergic toxicity are not associated with the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and recent medication history suggest serotonin syndrome, which is characterized by hyperthermia, agitation, tremors, and muscle rigidity. Increased CNS serotonergic activity is the most likely cause. Abnormal ryanodine receptor is associated with malignant hyperthermia, dopamine receptor blockade is associated with extrapyramidal symptoms, and anticholinergic toxicity is associated with dry mouth, blurred vision, and urinary retention.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the history of taking venlafaxine suggest serotonin syndrome due to increased CNS serotonergic activity. The impaired gait and tremors in all extremities are also signs of serotonin syndrome. Abnormal ryanodine receptor and dopamine receptor blockade are not related to the patient’s medications, and anticholinergic toxicity would show signs such as dry mouth and urinary retention, which were not mentioned in the patient’s presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest serotonin syndrome, which can be caused by taking two serotonergic medications together, in this case, citalopram and venlafaxine. The other options are not associated with these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing symptoms of serotonin syndrome, which can occur when two serotonergic drugs are used together. In this case, venlafaxine and citalopram are the likely culprits. Increased CNS serotonergic activity is the cause of the symptoms. The other options are not related to serotonin syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing symptoms of serotonin syndrome, which can occur when two or more drugs that increase serotonin levels are taken together. Venlafaxine and citalopram are both serotonin reuptake inhibitors. Symptoms of serotonin syndrome include hyperthermia, tachycardia, hypertension, tremors, and altered mental status. Options A, C, and D are not relevant to this presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest serotonin syndrome, which is caused by an excess of CNS serotonergic activity. Venlafaxine and citalopram are both serotonin reuptake inhibitors, and their combination may result in an excess of serotonin. The other options (abnormal ryanodine receptor, dopamine receptor blockade, anticholinergic toxicity) do not match the patient’s symptoms.
